html: In Jehovah’s Day of Judgment—at the time Isaiah’s prophecies come to pass—many of Jehovah’s people understand them. Those who were “blind” and “deaf”—his covenant people (Isaiah 42:16-20; 43:8)—then “see” and “hear” (Isaiah 32:3-4; 35:5). Having formerly “put darkness for light and light for darkness” (Isaiah 5:20), they then “see with their eyes and hear with their ears” (Isaiah 6:10). When Jehovah appoints his servant as “a light to the nations”—“to open eyes that are blind” and to deliver “those in darkness” (Isaiah 42:7; 49:6, 9; cf. 9:2)—humanity’s poor and lowly rejoice in Israel’s Holy One.
